awd_titl_txt: Statistically Sequence-Controlled Pharmaceutical Polymers, and Studies of Their Molecular Thermodynamic and Kinetic Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
The manipulation of monomer sequence as a means to produce structure and function in a polymer is well established for natural polymers, such as DNA and proteins.  However, for synthetic polymers it is prohibitively difficult, if not impossible, to precisely control the sequences of their building blocks. For applications in which low fidelity in sequence control is sufficient, a useful alternative to specific sequence control is to take a statistical approach, which may be preferable from a cost-benefit standpoint. The proposed research aims to use statistical sequence control to develop polymeric materials for drug delivery applications with improved biodegradation and drug release properties.  

The focus of the proposed research is to develop poly(D,L-lacticco- glycolic acid) (PLGA) copolyesters having improved biodegradation and drug release properties.  PLGA is the most prevalent polymeric material used in drug delivery applications. Currently, commercial PLGA polymers are produced by batch-type copolymerization reactions, which typically produce non-sequence-controlled "Gradient PLGA" copolymers because of the disparate reactivities of lactide (LA) and glycolide (GL) monomers toward polymerization. The proposed research will aim at advancing the fundamental understanding of ring-opening polymerization to control monomer sequence distribution along random copolymer PLGA, and developing a framework to understand how monomer sequence distribution affects drug encapsulation and release properties of the polymer. A set of structure-property studies is proposed to investigate the relationship between sequences and drug delivery. The scope of work is fundamental, and if successful, could have impact in both pharmaceutical and polymer research. The research project will provide integrated training for graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary environment and teach them skills that are necessary for developing the future generation of chemical engineering and polymer science researchers. Hands-on modules will be developed to demonstrate controlled release processes in outreach events. A Summer High School Research Experience Program is proposed and curriculum development is planned in the field of polymer, colloid and interface science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The present NSF grant (CBET-1803968, 9/2018 – 8/2022, titled “Statistically Sequence-Controlled Pharmaceutical Polymers, and Studies of Their Molecular Thermodynamic and Kinetic Properties”) has enabled us to develop a new, facile and scalable method (named the feed rate-controlled polymerization (FRCP) method) of producing sequence-controlled aliphatic copolyesters, such as uniform poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA). In this FRCP method, the comonomer mixture is continuously fed into the copolymerization at a sufficiently slow rate so that the disparity of the reactivities of the comonomers does not bias the monomer sequence distribution of the copolymer product, and as a result, monodisperse uniform copolyester products with non-gradient sequence characteristics can easily be produced. In this research, the FRCP method was used as a tool to address the gap that exists in this field, namely, the lack of understanding regarding the role that statistical monomer sequence plays in producing structural, degradation and drug encapsulation/release properties in PLGA materials. We found that when drug molecules are loaded into a matrix formed by uniform copolyester chains, the sequence uniformity forces the drug molecules to be more homogeneously distributed within the polymer matrix, which significantly suppresses the burst release of the drug and overall causes the release process to be more predictable, simple and uniform. Therefore, the FRCP method also offers a facile and scalable route for the production of non-gradient (precisely but) statistically monomer sequence-controlled uniform aliphatic copolyesters, such as uniform PLGA, for enhanced controlled release applications.

BROADER IMAPCTS

Poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) is a biodegradable, FDA-approved biocompatible, copolymer of lactide (LA) and glycolide (GL). PLGA is currently the most widely applied and successful polymeric material used in controlled drug delivery systems. There are over 20 commercialized drug products in which PLGA is used as an excipient. Traditionally, the knobs that are tuned in attempts to control the pharmacokinetic behaviors of PLGA-based drug products are primarily polymer molecular weight, monomer composition and polymer chain architecture. Prior to this work, the use of monomer sequence distribution at the statistical level to control the pharmacokinetic behaviors of PLGA formulations has gone almost completely unnoticed. Therefore, the findings of this research will have important implications on future PLGA-based product designs (for both new and generic drug products) in pharmaceutical industry; statistical sequence control may hold the key to solving the long-standing challenge associated with PLGA microencapsulation—a hard-to-predict, initial/multiphasic drug release behavior.

This research project also provided integrated training for involved postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary and collaborative environment to learn skills necessary for the future generation of polymer scientists and chemical engineers. A world-wide (PCT) patent application (entitled “Substantially Sequence-Uniform Aliphatic Copolyester and Method of Making the Same”) has been filed on the new FRCP (Feed Rate-Controlled Polymerization) technology developed in this project on May 13, 2022. We are considering performing an evaluation of the commercialization potential of this technology, for instance, through the NSF I-Corps in the upcoming year.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2022
Modified by: You-Yeon Won

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The present NSF grant (CBET-1803968, 9/2018 – 8/2022, titled "Statistically Sequence-Controlled Pharmaceutical Polymers, and Studies of Their Molecular Thermodynamic and Kinetic Properties") has enabled us to develop a new, facile and scalable method (named the feed rate-controlled polymerization (FRCP) method) of producing sequence-controlled aliphatic copolyesters, such as uniform poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA).
